rules.title: Konjunktiv I (Reported Speech)
rules.description: Used primarily for indirect speech in formal contexts and journalism.
examples: Er sagte, er sei müde. (He said he was tired.)
Sie behauptet, sie habe das nicht gewusst. (She claims she didn't know that.)
Der Minister erklärte, die Regierung werde neue Maßnahmen ergreifen. (The minister explained the government would take new measures.)
rules.notes: If Konjunktiv I form is identical to indicative, use Konjunktiv II instead.

rules.title: Modal Particles
rules.description: Small words that add nuance and attitude to statements, very common in spoken German.
examples: Das ist ja interessant! (That's interesting indeed!)
Komm doch mit! (Do come along!)
Das ist aber schön! (That's really nice!)
Was machst du denn hier? (What on earth are you doing here?)
rules.notes: Modal particles are unstressed and difficult to translate directly.

rules.title: Alternatives to Subjunctive
rules.description: Various constructions that can replace subjunctive forms in modern German.
examples: Er soll krank sein. (He is supposedly sick.)
Sie will das gesagt haben. (She claims to have said that.)
Das dürfte schwierig sein. (That is likely to be difficult.)
rules.notes: Using modal verbs + infinitive is increasingly common in place of Konjunktiv.

rules.title: Extended Participial Constructions
rules.description: Complex attributive constructions using present or past participles with modifiers, common in formal German.
examples: die seit Jahren andauernde Krise (the crisis continuing for years)
der von allen respektierte Professor (the professor respected by all)
die in den letzten Monaten stark gestiegenen Preise (the prices that have risen sharply in recent months)
das unter großem Aufwand durchgeführte Experiment (the experiment carried out with great effort)
rules.notes: These can usually be transformed into relative clauses in spoken German.

rules.title: Functional Verb Constructions (Funktionsverbgefüge)
rules.description: Fixed combinations of a verb and noun that together express a single meaning, common in formal/official language.
examples: eine Entscheidung treffen (to make a decision) instead of 'entscheiden'
in Betracht ziehen (to take into consideration) instead of 'betrachten'
zur Verfügung stellen (to make available) instead of 'verfügbar machen'
in Frage stellen (to question/challenge) instead of 'hinterfragen'
Kritik üben (to criticize) instead of 'kritisieren'
rules.notes: These constructions are characteristic of bureaucratic and academic German.

rules.title: Subjective Use of Modal Verbs
rules.description: Modal verbs used to express assumptions, hearsay, or the speaker's evaluation rather than objective facts.
examples: Sie muss krank sein. (She must be sick - assumption)
Er soll sehr reich sein. (He is said to be very rich - hearsay)
Das kann nicht stimmen. (That can't be right - speaker's judgment)
Er will nichts davon gewusst haben. (He claims not to have known anything about it)
Das dürfte das Ende sein. (That is probably the end - assumption)
rules.notes: Distinguished from objective modals by context and meaning. Often about probability or reported information.

rules.title: Advanced Conditional Sentences
rules.description: Complex conditional structures including irrealis and mixed conditionals.
examples: Hätte ich das gewusst, wäre ich nicht gekommen. (Had I known that, I wouldn't have come.)
Wenn ich mehr Zeit gehabt hätte, hätte ich es besser gemacht. (If I had had more time, I would have done it better.)
Sollte er kommen, sag ihm bitte Bescheid. (Should he come, please let him know.)
Wäre ich du, würde ich das nicht tun. (If I were you, I wouldn't do that.)
rules.notes: C1 level requires mastery of all conditional types, including those without 'wenn'.

rules.title: Advanced Nominalization
rules.description: Complex nominalization patterns in academic and formal writing.
examples: die Inbetriebnahme (the putting into operation)
die Inanspruchnahme (the claiming/utilizing)
die Durchführung der Maßnahmen (the implementation of the measures)
zur Verbesserung der Situation (for the improvement of the situation)
bei der Entstehung von Problemen (in the emergence of problems)
rules.notes: Heavy nominalization is typical of German bureaucratic and academic style.

rules.title: Discourse Markers and Connectors
rules.description: Advanced connectors that structure complex arguments and texts.
examples: allerdings (however/admittedly)
demzufolge / folglich (consequently)
insofern / inwiefern (insofar as / to what extent)
nichtsdestotrotz / nichtsdestoweniger (nevertheless)
einerseits...andererseits (on the one hand...on the other hand)
im Gegensatz zu / im Vergleich zu (in contrast to / in comparison to)
rules.notes: Essential for coherent academic and formal writing at C1 level.

rules.title: Prepositional Adverbs (da-/wo-compounds)
rules.description: Using da- and wo- compounds to refer to things (not people).
examples: Ich denke darüber nach. (I'm thinking about it.)
Worüber denkst du nach? (What are you thinking about?)
Er interessiert sich dafür. (He's interested in it.)
Wofür interessiert er sich? (What is he interested in?)
Damit bin ich nicht einverstanden. (I don't agree with that.)
rules.notes: Cannot be used for people. For people, use preposition + pronoun: 'über ihn', not 'darüber'.

rules.title: State Passive vs. Process Passive
examples: Process: Das Fenster wird geöffnet. (The window is being opened.)
State: Das Fenster ist geöffnet. (The window is open.)
Process: Der Brief wurde geschrieben. (The letter was written.)
State: Der Brief war geschrieben. (The letter was written - completed state)
Das Auto ist repariert. vs. Das Auto wird repariert.
rules.notes: Zustandspassiv uses sein + past participle (result), Vorgangspassiv uses werden + past participle (action).

rules.title: Konjunktiv II - Past Perfect
rules.description: Expressing hypothetical situations in the past.
examples: Wenn ich das gewusst hätte, hätte ich anders gehandelt. (If I had known that, I would have acted differently.)
Wäre ich früher gekommen, hätte ich sie noch getroffen. (Had I come earlier, I would have still met her.)
Das hätte nicht passieren dürfen. (That shouldn't have been allowed to happen.)
Sie wäre gerne mitgekommen. (She would have liked to come along.)
rules.notes: Formed with hätte/wäre + past participle. Essential for expressing regret and hypothetical past scenarios.

rules.title: Anticipatory 'es' with Subordinate Clauses
rules.description: Using 'es' to anticipate a following subordinate clause.
examples: Ich finde es wichtig, dass wir darüber sprechen. (I find it important that we talk about it.)
Er hält es für notwendig, neue Regeln einzuführen. (He considers it necessary to introduce new rules.)
Sie hat es geschafft, den Termin einzuhalten. (She managed to meet the deadline.)
Wir schätzen es sehr, dass Sie gekommen sind. (We very much appreciate that you came.)
rules.notes: 'Es' anticipates the real subject (the subordinate clause or infinitive) that comes later.

rules.title: Attributive vs. Predicative Adjectives
rules.description: Understanding when and why adjectives take different forms or meanings.
examples: Predicative: Der Mann ist arm. (The man is poor.)
Attributive: Der arme Mann. (The poor man - unfortunate)
ein alter Freund (an old friend - long-time) vs. ein Freund ist alt (a friend is old - elderly)
eine große Frau (a tall woman) vs. Die Frau ist groß. (The woman is tall.)
rules.notes: Some adjectives change meaning depending on position. Attributive adjectives require endings.

rules.title: Advanced Genitive Constructions
rules.description: Complex genitive structures in formal and academic German.
examples: die Rolle der Medien in der Gesellschaft (the role of the media in society)
im Rahmen der Diskussion (within the framework of the discussion)
aufgrund dessen (on the basis of that)
angesichts der Tatsache (in view of the fact)
hinsichtlich der Frage (with regard to the question)
rules.notes: Heavy genitive usage is characteristic of formal written German.

rules.title: Register Switching and Style
rules.description: Adapting language to different contexts: formal, informal, academic, colloquial.
examples: Formal: Ich möchte Sie darauf aufmerksam machen... (I would like to draw your attention to...)
Informal: Hör mal, weißt du was? (Hey, you know what?)
Academic: Es lässt sich feststellen, dass... (It can be established that...)
Colloquial: Klar, kein Ding! (Sure, no problem!)
rules.notes: C1 speakers must navigate different registers appropriately for different situations.

rules.title: Nominal Style (Nominalstil)
rules.description: The German preference for noun-heavy constructions in formal writing.
examples: Verbal: nachdem er ankam → Nominal: nach seiner Ankunft (after his arrival)
Verbal: weil er versagte → Nominal: wegen seines Versagens (because of his failure)
Verbal: bevor man entscheidet → Nominal: vor der Entscheidung (before the decision)
die Durchführung der Untersuchung (the carrying out of the investigation)
rules.notes: Nominal style is more concise and formal. Very common in bureaucratic and academic texts.

rules.title: Complex Relative Clauses
rules.description: Nested and interrupted relative clauses with prepositions.
examples: Der Grund, aus dem er gekommen ist, ist unklar. (The reason for which he came is unclear.)
Die Art und Weise, in der sie arbeitet, ist beeindruckend. (The way in which she works is impressive.)
Menschen, deren Meinung ich respektiere, sagen das Gegenteil. (People whose opinion I respect say the opposite.)
Das Haus, in dem ich geboren wurde, steht noch. (The house in which I was born still stands.)
rules.notes: Prepositions can come before the relative pronoun. 'Dessen/deren' for genitive relatives.

rules.title: Advanced Particle Verbs and Prefixes
rules.description: Understanding subtle meaning changes with different prefixes.
examples: verstehen (understand) vs. missverstehen (misunderstand) vs. entstehen (emerge)
erklären (explain) vs. verklären (transfigure) vs. aufklären (enlighten)
schätzen (estimate/value) vs. unterschätzen (underestimate) vs. abschätzen (assess)
bedenken (consider) vs. überdenken (reconsider) vs. nachdenken (think about)
rules.notes: Prefixes can completely change verb meaning. Nuance matters at C1 level.
